name: spiranthes-cernua
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern Canada to Texas and Florida
light: Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Fertilized flowers are replaced by pods containing the tiny seeds, which are easily carried aloft by the wind. These pods may be capable of photosynthesis while they are green.
flower-description: Small, white, fragrant, slightly downward-curved, double lipped flowers in a double spiral on 8 to 18 inch stem that bloom in September and October.
leaf-description: Three to four slender 12 inch leaves. Lance-shaped, linear leaves in basal rosettes, with some leaves extending up the flower spikes. The leaves have smooth margins and usually wither away before the flowers bloom. On robust specimens, there may be 1 or 2 small leaves on the lower flowering stalk.
stem-description: The flowering stalk has 6 to12 flowers occurring on the upper half. Flowers are densely arranged in vertical, slightly spiral-like rows on spikes typically growing 9 to 18 inches tall (sometimes 24 inches).
